Message.Title: KARL;Amazon Buyers: Did You READ The Report?
Message.Msg: Amazon Buyers: Did You READ The Report? I have to wonder. After all, the numbers are right here. Let's just cut the #$%$ and get to the facts. Free cash flow decreased to $395 million -- on sales of $.27 billion, or 0.065%. That sucks. It's also down 81% from last year when it was $2.09 billion on $48.08 billion (4.35%, which is still pretty #$%$.) Net income was down 45% as well. And while full year sales were up 27%, net was down on the higher sales amount, and so was operating income on a full year basis! In fact it was down 22%! Transition says Bezos? Like hell. Further, net sales are forecast under estimates for the next quarter and the company's operating income range is wider on the negative (loss) side than positive. Everyone wants to talk about the increased cash position. Did you notice where it came from? The company sold just over $3 billion in debt -- but the cash position increased by about half that. Worse, depreciation and amortization roughly doubled! Doubled folks, while sales were up 27%. That's not good, it's bad! Your depreciation and amortization should not be rising faster than sales; if it is you're becoming less efficient, not more. It's good that payables were lower at year end and receivables were inline -- that's positive and means your control of both vendors and customer credit is reasonable. Fulfillment expenses were up 36% in the last three months -- and up 47% on the year -- while sales were up 27%. Remember that some sales are digital in format and have near-zero fulfillment expense. This is not good either; fulfillment expenses increasing faster than sales is again an indication of efficiency problems. In this case that increase is not small either, especially on a full-year basis. Fulfillment expenses rising at nearly double the rate of sales increase is especially troubling! G&A is rising faster too -- 36% on the year. And while interest expense is relatively modest at $92 million, it now is more than double interest income, where last year it was near-parity. That, of course, came from selling that $3 billion (roughly) in new debt, and will continue to be there in the future. And by the way, without that interest expense the company would have made a profit on the year. A small profit... but a profit. Oh, and if that's not enough, growth is slowing. A lot. By 38% in the last quarter of the year (compared to 2011) and by 30% on the full year. Forward stock price multiple expansion is supposed to come from increasing sales growth on a percentage basis, not contracting. Of particular concern is the fact that electronics and general merchandise sales growth rates for the last three months -- Christmas Season -- dropped approximately in half from last year. While media increased a bunch it's also only about a third of the size of general merchandise. "Other" is inconsequential; about 7% of the whole. This chart from the release says it all: The market is ramping this firm's stock price into a deteriorating growth story. IMHO you're nuts. View this entry with comments (registration required to post)

Message.Title: No Shipping Cost Efficiencies Seen From Building New Fulfillment Centers
Message.Msg: Increased operating margin and decreased net shipping cost as a % of sales are both largely due to Amazon CHARGING more for shipping, not decreasing shipping cost. Shipping cost was up 23%, largely in line with unit increases due to NON-THIRD PARTY SALES(sales of Amazon's products), while year over year shipping revenue was up 57%. In last year's 4th quarter shipping revenue was up only 21% from prior year. If shipping revenue had risen at the same rate as the prior year net shipping cost would still approximate 5.5% of sales. Another load of #$%$ that building these new centers closer to customers is saving on shipping expense.

Message.Title: Evercore Partners Lifts PT on Amazon to $330 on Margin Improvement
Message.Msg: Evercore Partners Lifts PT on Amazon (AMZN) to $330 on Margin Improvement Evercore Partners analyst Ken Sena raised its price target on Overweight-rated Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) from $290 to $330 following Q4 results, which missed on revenues although margins accelerated. The firm notes gross profit dollar growth of 42.5% (vs. 38% estimated) and 37% in the prior year. On this, the analyst comments, "we find the favorable mix shift towards higher gross margin businesses (e.g., 3P and Other/AWS) to be well underway." On the revenue, the firm notes revenues increased 22% y/y, 600 bps below the 28% we had been anticipating. Given this, Sena is reducing 2013 revenue estimate 6% to $75 billion. They are also lowering long-term revenue growth estimate by 500bps on average to the low 20s y/y vs. high 20s previously. "We reiterate that this revenue reduction is estimated to come from Amazon's lower gross margin 1P retail revenues, thereby minimizing the impact to gross profitability," the analystcomments. Sena notes gross margin improvement to outweigh revenue deceleration. "To arrive at this conclusion, we breakdown the gross profit contribution historically among 1P retail revenues (booked gross of COGS), 3P retail revenues (booked net), and Other/AWS revenues where expenses also fall below the gross profit line. What we found is that faster steady growth from 3P unit sales and Other/AWS is likely to driver higher blended gross margins (i.e., 30%+ in three years), even assuming no future gross margin expansion within Amazon's 1P retail business. Therefore, even on lower 1Q13 and 2013 estimates and lower revenue estimates over the near and long-term, we are modeling higher overall gross profit dollar growth."

Topic.Title: RETAIL SHOULD DEPLOY LEAP PUTS TOMORROW ON ANY SCAM PUMP BY FRAUD STREET ON SCAMAZON

Message.Msg: I have to wonder. After all, the numbers are right here. Let's just cut the #$%$ and get to the facts. Free cash flow decreased to $395 million -- on sales of $.27 billion, or 0.065%. That sucks. It's also down 81% from last year when it was $2.09 billion on $48.08 billion (4.35%, which is still pretty #$%$.) Net income was down 45% as well. And while full year sales were up 27%, net was down on the higher sales amount, and so was operating income on a full year basis! In fact it was down 22%! Transition says Bezos? Like hell. Further, net sales are forecast under estimates for the next quarter and the company's operating income range is wider on the negative (loss) side than positive. Everyone wants to talk about the increased cash position. Did you notice where it came from? The company sold just over $3 billion in debt -- but the cash position increased by about half that. Worse, depreciation and amortization roughly doubled! Doubled folks, while sales were up 27%. That's not good, it's bad! Your depreciation and amortization should not be rising faster than sales; if it is you're becoming less efficient, not more. It's good that payables were lower at year end and receivables were inline -- that's positive and means your control of both vendors and customer credit is reasonable. Fulfillment expenses were up 36% in the last three months -- and up 47% on the year -- while sales were up 27%. Remember that some sales are digital in format and have near-zero fulfillment expense. This is not good either; fulfillment expenses increasing faster than sales is again an indication of efficiency problems. In this case that increase is not small either, especially on a full-year basis. Fulfillment expenses rising at nearly double the rate of sales increase is especially troubling! G&A is rising faster too -- 36% on the year. And while interest expense is relatively modest at $92 million, it now is more than double interest income, where last year it was near-parity. That, of course, came from selling that $3 billion (roughly) in new debt, and will continue to be there in the future. And by the way, without that interest expense the company would have made a profit on the year. A small profit... but a profit. Oh, and if that's not enough, growth is slowing. A lot. By 38% in the last quarter of the year (compared to 2011) and by 30% on the full year. Forward stock price multiple expansion is supposed to come from increasing sales growth on a percentage basis, not contracting. Of particular concern is the fact that electronics and general merchandise sales growth rates for the last three months -- Christmas Season -- dropped approximately in half from last year. While media increased a bunch it's also only about a third of the size of general merchandise. "Other" is inconsequential; about 7% of the whole. This chart from the release says it all: The market is ramping this firm's stock price into a deteriorating growth story.

Message.Title: Beware Amazon FCF
Message.Msg: Amazon pays its workers with stock. $800 million or so last year. They don't subtract that against FCF even though it is akin to paying workers in cash and having them buy the stock from you the next day. AMZN does not count capital leases as capital expenditures even though it raises PPE and is equivalent to issuing debt for long term use of building. These two items alon reduce their FCF by $1.6 to $1.7 billion. In other words no FCF. Momo boys may have their way. I can get a $282 valuation with momo boy assumptions. Long run 5% margins, growth of 24%, 21%, 20, 18% and then slowly tapering down to 4% steady state 15 years from today. I only use a 9.1% discount rate for what is a very risky stock. I don't even adjust for FCF being back end loaded which means the PV is overstated (Q1 will have negative FCF and Q4 very positive). Time value of money it matters. In other words everything goes off without a hitch. So, as Doug Kass says never short on valuation (alone). If that were the case I would be running to short Netflix. Ride, ride, ride, let it ride. I suspect analysts will forecast EPS and revenues above likely outcome. Wait till around 4 days before next earnigns and if it is sitting over $300 go for it.

Message.Title: From Cramer on Dynavax
Message.Msg: Dynavax Technologies (DVAX), a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, discovers and develops novel products to prevent and treat infectious diseases, asthma and inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. This stock closed up 3.6% to $3.15 on Tuesday. Tuesday's Range: $3.01-$3.21 52-Week Range: $2.22-$5.34 Volume: 6.07 million Three-Month Average Volume: 3.76 million From a technical perspective, DVAX spiked higher here right off its 50-day moving average of $2.92 with massive upside volume. This move is quickly pushing shares of DVAX within range of triggering a major breakout trade. That trade will hit if DVAX manages to take out some near-term overhead resistance at $3.39 with high volume. Traders should now look for long-biased trades in DVAX as long as it’s trending above its 50-day at $2.92, and then once it sustains a move or close above $3.39 with volume that hits near or above 3.76 million shares. If that breakout triggers soon, then DVAX will set up to re-fill some of its gap down zone from last November that started around $4.75. Some possible upside targets if DVAX gets into that gap are its 200-day at $3.90 to $4.25.

Message.Msg: I like Amazon and use Amazon at least monthly. The company itself and the concept is great, but from a financial perspective its a flawed business model. And retailers are starting to get more aggressive so things most likely will get worse. This stock needs to go down from here.

Topic.Title: Piper Jaffray's Gene Munster Raises Margin Forecast to 8%

Message.Msg: Gene sometimes drinks too much koolaid t’s the most intriguing investing question of our time: How high can Apple’s stock go? Answering that query has propelled the career of Gene Munster, a research analyst at Minneapolis brokerage firm Piper Jaffray . For the better part of a decade, Munster, 40, has consistently urged investors to put money into Apple, and he’s been right: The shares have gone from $16.25, when he first recommended them in June 2004, to $628 on April 10. In 2012 alone, the stock is up 56 percent, adding $208 billion to Apple’s market value. At almost $600 billion, Apple is by far the most highly valued company in the world.Now Munster is upping the ante, calling for Apple to reach $1,000 a share by 2014 and become the first U.S. company worth $1 trillion. (Beijing-basedPetroChina crossed that mark for a day in November 2007.)

Topic.Title: Shorts why are you ignoring AMZN's margin expansion?

Message.Msg: I'm not short but it's because the fundamentals and outlook are terrible. And the margin is terrible. It's only slightly less terrible than it was last qtr. At some point, reality will set in. It has to and always does eventually. When it does, Bezos will have to either provide share-holder value instead of share-holder promises or the stock will adjust to typical multiples afforded a retailer such as Target and Walmart. If it's the latter (and if the economy turns soon, that's more likely), then the adjustment to reality will suck all the air out of AMZN space-helmets overnight. If it's the former, then AMZN will still be worth less than it is today. So it's hard to feel like AMZN will be the first ever stock to avoid realism of the market. Eventually it finds the real value and enforces it. GL.

Topic.Title: Straddle strategy

Message.Msg: Option 101 - Implied Volatity: Prior to earnings. Anxieties build; hence, implied volatility goes up. Sometimes way up. IV drives option prices higher. Now that the earnings are out, people stop buying them which translates into cheaper option pricing. Straddle is good for some circumstances, but for earning plays, option traders sell option contracts into earnings for high IV values. Because contracts are more expensive to sell and cheaper to buy and options don't need precise stock pricing to win (in many cases). Buying options prior to earnings generally are riskier than selling them.

Topic.Title: RETAIL SHOULD DEPLOY LEAP PUTS TOMORROW ON ANY SCAM PUMP BY FRAUD STREET ON SCAMAZON

Message.Msg: The only place that I truly see them with a long term sustainable competitive advantage is in the third party fulfillment market. Other than that I think with sales tax their low cost advantage is over and probably showed in big $ items slowing down last qtr. I bought a Nikon camera at Best Buy online that was slightly cheaper than amazon during Christmas. In streaming they will be competing heavily with NFLX which is investing tons of money and will make little return on investment. For AMZN to compete they will need to do the same thing and that will add nothing to bottom line. In hardware they already sell their stuff at cost or below. Competing with AAPL and Sumsung, Nokia, MSFT, and Blackberry. Good luck there. In AWS they are dealing with a whole list of new competitors. Good luck there. IT will eventually get to what are you willing to pay for an effecient online fulfillment service. Definitely not this multiple. I see this in the 6th Inning. Similar to NFLX when it was in the 200's. BTW I have been also watching those current assets/liabilities. If it continues in this fashion only way for them to continue investing in all those above activities will be to continue issuing debt. 3B is managable with low rates but if they continue borrowing it will be an issue at some point.

Topic.Title: Look at todays UPGRADES and Reiterates! Never seen so many in one day..DEMISE is fast approaching

Message.Msg: "Apple took that huge hit despite delivering a record breaking quarter." But this is normal for most stocks that underperform expectations regardless of whether it is a record breaking quarter or not. The stock gets clobbered. "Long-term Apple will have many challenges, but they have a ton of cash and huge earnings." Cash is less of a factor for a company that doesn't know how to use it appropriately. It is part of the reason Apple has so much cash, they don't spend enough of it. And part of that comes from Jobs' policy to focus only on a small number of products in order to do them very, very well, exceeding what other conventional electronics producers do, which is to spread themselves too thin. Companies that can't put cash to use tend to be priced at lower multiples like MSFT and others. This is where Apple is headed the more and more it begins to resemble MSFT in this way. Ironically, Amazon takes its cash and reinvests it heavily. So they have much less cash in the bak than they would have otherwise in the short-term at least. And shorts take this as a sign of weakness. Nothing could be further from the truth, and the market recognizes this with Amazon. That they have so many great opportunities to invest and expand whereas Apple simply doesn't. "I think the street just doesn't like Tim Cook." No, they don't like it when they fail to meet expectations. Cook failed, if he'd exceeded expectations they'd have loved him. Has nothing to do with him personally. "If they fall in love with the person, like Bezos" No, they fall in love with those who can continue to find great opportunities to expand their business and have a willingness to pursue them aggressively. Bezos just happens to be one of those names that does this best. "Reed Hastings (NFLX)...then they can do no wrong." NFLX just posted something like 70% growth. I think they fell in love with expectations being blown away on Wall Street. Too bad if NFLX shorts got blown away, too. "Obama..." Even if no one fell in love with, you can't make a strong argument that the other side had much to offer and thus giving voters no real reason to overwhelmingly overturn the status quo.

Topic.Title: CRAMMER SEZ AMZN HAS NO COMPETTION

Message.Msg: If you think the only thing Amazon has going for it is no sales tax, you are blind. I live in Washington State and have to pay tax to Amazon. I've gone from buying a few items a year from Amazon about ten years ago to where I spend probably $10,000 a year now and I just keep buying more and more from them. Basically, I'm to the point where I buy almost everything except food from Amazon. I rarely go to a store other than a grocery store. They have a selection that nobody else has, great prices (on most items, not all), the convienience is unmatched and the customer service is the best I've ever seen. The only time I don't buy from Amazon is when I have to have something right away and as same day delivery becomes available, that will take care of that problem.

Topic.Title: CRAMMER SEZ AMZN HAS NO COMPETTION

Message.Msg: Let's decompose Cramer's ridonculous statement: Large retail segments: 1) Autos -- Mainly still a dealer based, physical business. Cars and AutoDealer are well established online. 2) Restaurants -- An inherently local business aside from reservations and carry out. OPEN and GRPN already dominate this segment as it relates to online companies extracting value. 3) Gasoline -- No play here at all 4) Service businesses -- peraonal care, etc... Already dominated by GRPN. Living Social getting whooped here... Again, limited role/ability for Amazon to extract value given its assets/capabalities are mainly related to physical goods logistics... 5) Grocery -- Some opportunity but Amazon Fresh and Peapod have been pushing this for year. Consumer behavior and purchase habits make this tough to serve profitably (except in certain urban areas like NYC...). That's just a start. The more finely one segments, the more one realizes what BS Cramer's pump was... Larry, you seem to be the new retail expert and a fan of buying here. Maybe you can help us understand how Amazon will dominate all these segments and, more importantly, how the profitability of the categories Amazon is expanding into will compare to the high value density electronics category that it has already largely saturated...
